item.title: New Avatar: Frontiers Of Pandora DLC Arrives Same Day As Fire And Ash Movie
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Avatar: Frontiers of Pandora, Ubisoft Massive's open-world action game set within James Cameron's Avatar cinematic universe, is getting another expansion during the Christmas season. This new DLC, titled From the Ashes, drops on December 19, the same day Avatar: Fire and Ash hits theaters--in case you needed more Avatar.

Revealed by IGN, From the Ashes sees you play as the battle-hardened Trr’ong clan Na'vi So'lek, who sets out to protect his family after the RDA and its new allies--the violent Ash clan--ambushed and left him for dead.

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

Now Playing: Avatar: Frontiers of Pandora Review

Creative director Omar Bouali told IGN that From the Ashes takes place "a few weeks" after the upcoming Fire and Ash film and "roughly six months" after the events of Frontiers of Pandora and its two previous story expansions (The Sky Breaker and Secrets of the Spires).

"From the Ashes is set in a ravaged and occupied version of the Kinglor Forest which includes a new sub-region, The Ravines," Bouali said. "It mirrors the themes of the film as it sees the RDA ally with the Ash Clan, fierce Na’vi warriors who thrive on chaos and pain as they intensify their efforts to eliminate threats to their regime. So, whilst the film and expansion are set in different regions of Pandora, there is some shared DNA and we've worked closely with Lightstorm to ensure both pieces of Avatar media are [complementary]."

Keeping his cards close to his chest and choosing his words carefully, Bouali gave a brief hint of what to expect when From the Ashes comes out this December. Apparently, there's a connection between this upcoming story expansion and the upcoming theatrical release.

"We have been able to share some elements across both pieces of media--the most obvious being the Mangkawn, otherwise known as the Ash Clan, but also the Wind Traders who appeared first in our game but will also appear in Fire and Ash," Bouali said. "There’s also one very special creature that will appear in both our game and Fire and Ash that we’re very excited for fans to discover. So yes, without revealing too much, it is a process of strong collaboration and we each have been able to share and contribute in an organic, complementary way to ensure fans get an authentic and consistent experience across both the expansion and film."

This isn't the only thing coming to Frontiers of Pandora. On December 5, two weeks before From the Ashes and Fire and Ash come out, Ubisoft Massive will release an update for the open-world action-adventure game that introduces New Game Plus, as well as a third-person camera for a different perspective.

From the Ashes will be available for $20 USD on PS5, Xbox Series X|S, Ubisoft+, and PC via Steam, Epic Games Store, and Ubisoft Connect. There's also a $40 USD From the Ashes Edition, which includes the base Frontiers of Pandora game and this story DLC.

Avatar: Frontiers of Pandora is available now on PC, PS5, and Xbox Series X|S.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Palworld Is Getting Its Own Cozy Game Spin-Off
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Earlier in September, Nintendo revealed that Pokemon is getting a cozy game, Pokemon Pokopia. Apparently the developers of Palworld had similar ideas, because Pocketpair has now unveiled a spin-off cozy game of its own called Palworld: Palfarm.

Much like Pokemon Pokopia, Palfarm lets players gather pals to help them live a quiet life as a farmer while handling the harvest, the cooking, and even the business of selling the food. The chosen pals also lend their special abilities to the player to make things easier on the farm.

However, it does appear that this game has a dark side. Pocketpair has confirmed that some pals will attack the communities you create in Palfarm. The trailer also has an unnerving sequence of a gunshop owner playing with a weapon that's much darker than the Pokemon games are willing to go.

Palworld: Palfarm is available to wish list on Steam, but it hasn't been confirmed for any of the consoles yet. The game's release date is currently unannounced.

In the interim, Nintendo has stepped up its legal battle against Pocketpair over Palworld's similarities to Pokemon. Pocketpair has removed some of the features that Nintendo objected to, but now the latter has cited a patent that “covers the fundamental gameplay mechanic of summoning a character and letting it fight another” in a video game.

As part of the same case, Nintendo recently argued that mods don't count as either games or "prior art." While there's no settlement in sight between the two sides, Pocketpair is moving forward with an ambitious slate of updates for Palworld that will arrive in 2026.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com
